article.name: Phish Alert Button (PAB) for Microsoft 365 Guide
article.title: Phish Alert Button (PAB) for Microsoft 365 Guide
article.body:
The Phish Alert Button (PAB) is a tool that allows you to report potentially malicious emails, such as phishing emails. When you use the PAB to report a potentially malicious email, you can help keep your organization safe from cyberattacks.

When Should I Use the PAB?

You should use the PAB to report any suspicious emails or potential phishing emails. When you use the PAB to report an email, the email will be automatically deleted from your inbox and forwarded to your IT security team.

You should not use the PAB to report spam or marketing emails. You can delete these types of emails or add the sender or sender's email domain to a block list.

Important:If you need help adding a sender to a block list, contact your supervisor or IT team.

How Do I Use the PAB?

The steps for reporting an email using the PAB may vary based on the app that you're using. When you report an email using the PAB, the reported email will be automatically forwarded to your IT team regardless of the app that you're using.

Click the links below to learn how to use the PAB for the apps that you're using:

  • Using the PAB in Microsoft 365
  • Using the PAB in the Microsoft Outlook Mobile App for Android
  • Using the PAB in the Microsoft Outlook Mobile App for Apple iOS

If you report an email in error, you can retrieve the email from your Trash or Deleted Items folders.

Note:The PAB is only compatible on mobile devices with public instances of Microsoft. Due to the permissions required, the PAB cannot be used on mobile devices with Microsoft 365 GCC High.

Using the PAB in Microsoft 365

If you use Microsoft 365, follow the steps below to report an email with the PAB:

  1. Open the email that you would like to report.
  2. Click the Apps icon in the top-right corner of the email to open the Apps launcher. Or, click the ellipsis icon (...) and select Apps.
  3. From the Apps launcher that opens, click the Phish Alert add-in.

    Note:If the PAB add-in is not displayed in the Apps launcher, click Add apps. Then, locate and add the PAB add-in.You can also pin the PAB add-in to the toolbar at the top of an open email. To pin the add-in, click the ellipsis icon and select Customize actions. Or, navigate to Settings > Mail > Customize actions. Then, select the Phish Alert add-in and click Save. For more information about managing add-ins in Microsoft Office, visit Microsoft's Get an Office Add-in for Outlook article.
  4. In the prompt that opens, click Phish Alert again to report the email.

    Note:If your admin has enabled the Comments and Dispositions setting for the PAB, you can select a disposition from the Email Classification section. The Unknown option is selected by default. You can also enter a comment about the email you are reporting. Then, click Phish Alert.
  5. After you click Phish Alert again, a message will display to confirm that you reported the email. This message will tell you if the email you reported was a simulated phishing attack or if the email will need to be reviewed by your IT team. To close this message, click Ok.

Using the PAB in the Microsoft Outlook Mobile App for Android

If you use the Microsoft Outlook app for Android, follow the steps below to report an email:

  1. Open the email that you would like to report.
  2. Click the vertical ellipsis icon (...) at the upper right corner of the email. Check the rest of the screen if you do not see the button in this location.
  3. Click the Phish Alert icon.
  4. In the pop-up window that opens, click Phish Alert to report the email.

    Note:If your admin has enabled the Comments and Dispositions setting for the PAB, you can select a disposition from the Email Classification section. The Unknown option is selected by default. You can also enter a comment about the email you are reporting. Then, click Phish Alert.
  5. After you click Phish Alert again, a message will display to confirm that you reported the email. This message will tell you if the email you reported was a simulated phishing attack or if the email will need to be reviewed by your IT team. To close this message, click Ok.

Using the PAB in the Microsoft Outlook Mobile App for Apple iOS

If you use the Microsoft Outlook app for Apple iOS, follow the steps below to report an email:

  1. Open the email that you would like to report.
  2. Click the ellipsis icon (…) at the upper right corner of the email.
  3. Click the Phish Alert icon.
  4. In the pop-up window that opens, click Phish Alert again to report the email.

    Note:If your admin has enabled the Comments and Dispositions setting for the PAB, you can select a disposition from the Email Classification section. The Unknown option is selected by default. You can also enter a comment about the email you are reporting. Then, click Phish Alert.
  5. After you click Phish Alert again, a message will display to confirm that you reported the email. This message will tell you if the email you reported was a simulated phishing attack or if the email will need to be reviewed by your IT team. To close this message, click Ok.

Why Should I Use the PAB?

When you use the PAB to report suspicious emails, you can help keep your organization safe from security threats. The reported emails are sent to your organization for analysis, which will help keep your IT team informed about potential phishing emails that their employees receive. Once your IT team is aware of potential threats, they can help your organization stay safe from future attacks.

This image displays an application selection pane, likely within a Microsoft 365 or Outlook interface.

**UI Elements and Layout:**
1.  **Search Bar:** The top of the pane features a search field labeled "Find an app" accompanied by a magnifying glass icon.
2.  **Application Icons:** Four primary application icons are displayed in the visible grid:
    *   **Report Message:** An icon depicting an envelope, a shield, and an exclamation mark.
    *   **Send to OneNote:** The purple Microsoft OneNote ('N') icon.
    *   **Share to Teams:** The purple and teal Microsoft Teams ('T') icon.
    *   **Phish Alert:** The primary focus element. This icon depicts an envelope containing the letters "H TCT" overlaid with an orange fishing hook.
3.  **Instructional Marker:** A prominent, thick, orange arrow points directly toward the "Phish Alert" icon, indicating the required selection.
4.  **Action Button:** A button is located at the bottom right corner of the pane, labeled "Add apps" and accompanied by a plus sign icon.

**Context:** The panel presents a list of available integrations or actions, designed to allow the user to select an app (specifically "Phish Alert") to interact with the current context (likely an email or message).

This image depicts a modal dialogue box, labeled "**Phish Alert**," used to confirm the reporting of a suspected phishing email, likely within a Microsoft 365 integrated environment.

**UI Elements and Text Content:**

1.  **Header:** The title is "**Phish Alert**," accompanied by an icon depicting an envelope with a fishing hook. A standard 'X' icon is present on the right for dismissing the dialogue.
2.  **Branding and Context:** The dialogue displays the brand name "**KnowBe4**." A blue contextual label reading "**M365**" is positioned near the branding, indicating integration with Microsoft 365.
3.  **Confirmation Prompt:** The central text asks, "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?"
4.  **Email Metadata Display:** The dialogue provides summary information about the email being reported:
    *   **Subject:** "New Voice Mail!"
    *   **From Field:** This information is presented in a separate, outlined box. The sender name is "**VoIP Message**," and the associated sender email address is visible but blurred (suggesting a format like `voicemail@internal.voipmessage.com`).
5.  **Action Button:** A full-width, solid blue primary action button is located at the bottom of the screen, confirming the report action. The button text is "**Phish Alert**."
6.  **Extraneous Element:** An unrelated, large orange arrow is superimposed over the screenshot, pointing down toward the primary action button.

A modal dialog box, presented against a white background with slightly rounded corners, confirms a user action related to security training.

**UI Elements and Layout:**
*   **Title Bar:** Displays the heading "Phish Alert" in bold, black text on the top left.

This image is a screenshot of a mobile email client utilizing a dark theme, displaying a single opened message concerning a safety recall.

**UI and Context:**
*   **Application/Device Context:** The device status bar indicates the time is 10:11 and the battery level is 53%. The application header contains standard controls: Back arrow, Voice Input/Search icon, Delete icon, Archive/Save icon, and an Overflow Options menu (vertical ellipsis).
*   **Email Subject and Verification:** The subject line is "Safety recall for your vehicle." Immediately below, a security alert is displayed via a gray pill-shaped element labeled "Unverified" (accompanied by a user and question mark icon), indicating the sender's identity could not be confirmed.
*   **Sender and Timestamp:** The sender is listed as "Pamela C." with the secondary identifier "Test User." The message received date is "Yesterday."

**Content and Attachments:**
*   **Attachment:** The message includes a Microsoft Word document attachment displayed in a rectangular block: "SourceMessage.docm" (type DOCM, size 205 KB). This block also features a vertical ellipsis for attachment options.
*   **Body Text Snippet:** The visible body text begins with "Dear Valued Customer," and informs the recipient that their "auto manufacturer has issued a safety-related defect for certain vehicles." The text promises repairs will be "completed at no cost to you."

**Interaction Elements:**
*   **Smart Replies:** Two suggested reply buttons are present below the email content: "What does this mean?" and "Thank you for letting me know."
*   **Reply Bar:** The bottom interaction section shows a drop-down arrow and left arrow icon adjacent to the text "Reply."
*   **Annotation:** A large, non-UI orange arrow points toward the three-dot overflow menu located near the "Yesterday" timestamp.

**Navigation:**
*   The system navigation bar at the bottom displays the standard Android controls (Recent Apps, Home, Back).
